Her point, that a methodical, empirical, investigative methodology is not unique to science, is well made (for a good summary, read this review). Basically she points out that good research and investigation is good research and investigation whether it was done by a historian (or any profession) or scientist.

Even modern forensic science (much less historical study) is limited by the "degree of activity" of the crime scene. A "fresh" crime scene is more reliable than an older crime scene. The "activenes" of a subject does matter.

 
 Yes and no. New tools and techniques appear daily and what was not accessible at an active scene say 50 years back might well be quite accessible today even on the much aged evidence which might still be available.

BTW, I doubt this statement would make it very far in a scientific journal: "Is this theory sound? I don't know...but it wouldn't surprise me if it is." Such a statement would be good enough for historical conjecture...further demonstrating the difference between the two fields.

 
 Well you might be suprised at how speculative one can get in a scientific journal. After all look at how the papers are organized. There are the strictly technical sections, a conclusion section where one is obligated to make supported logical inferences, and a discussion section (often combined with the conclusions) in which researchers sometimes explore the more speculative aspects of their work. After science is not afraid of creating new hypotheses to be tested and possibly shot down by fellow scientists - its the life blood of the field. Absent speculation everything would grind to a halt. I always liked the closing statement of Watson and Cricks first report on DNA structure --- "The implications of this has not escaped us" or words to that effect!

...So in some sense your limits are true, however they are likely to be much broader (active,available) than you might have thought.

 I think you are correct that the limits I am suggesting are broader than initially thought. I would add to this that not only are they are broader, but structured on a scale of verifiability (or falsifiability, as it were).
 
 
Yes and no. New tools and techniques appear daily and what was not accessible at an active scene say 50 years back might well be quite accessible today even on the much aged evidence which might still be available.

 True, but these tools actually make the point that science is in the business of studying active/available subjects. These tools are made and used to make up for the lack of activity/availability by magnifying what little activity/availability is present.

Life is dependent on cyclic processes which are self sustaining only so long as there is an input of energy and matter. Remove those inputs for more than a fairly short length of time and the autocatalytic system naturally grinds to a halt. Automobiles are not self-catalytic absent inputs of matter and energy their structures are stable. Not so with a living organism which is only alive if it remains far from thermodynamic equilibrium a process which requires constant and nearly unremitting physical work.

 
 **
 And once again you support my point--that organic death and mechanical breakdown are too qualitatively different to serve as comparitive analogies for one another.

Nope many "thermostats" are evolved systems which arise without intention or purpose.

 
 **
 Stuff and nonsense. I do not know why you put "thermostats" in quotes, because a thermostat is a thermostat, and it is always a man-made artefact that seves a human purpose. Such tools do not "evolve" omn their own, without human intention or purpose.
 
 If, OTH, you wish to speak speak of organismic internal temperature regulation systems, then do no speak of thermostats, because an organism is not a 'thermostat', whether it is cold-blooded, warm-blooded, or anywhere in between.
 
 Here, for your edification, (and because you never consult a dictionary before dictating to the world the meaning you have chosen to bestow upon a word), 
 is the definition of "thermostat".
 
 "ther·mo·stat (thûr'mə-stăt') 
 n.
 A device, as in a home heating system, a refrigerator, or an air conditioner, that automatically responds to temperature changes and activates switches controlling the equipment."
 
 This plain definition is elaborated upon at answers.com, but this one says it all, FAPP.
 
 Now, you are no doubt going to try to fog things up a bit by pretending that our planet, with it's 'heat distribution' mechanisms, is some kind of,
 'thermostat'. It is not.
 
 
 Failing that, you will try for ' temperature self-regulating mechanical system'. It isn't that either. The earth's temperature, overall, is beyond any 'self-control' of any kind, (or indeed, any external contol beyond what humans may or may not accomplish re global warming). It is strictly the effect of external forces. If for discussion purposes we create a figure of speech wherebye the human race acts as this world's thermostat, that would be fine by me. But if we do, it is the onw and only "thermostat" in existence that can be called an "evolved system[]", and whether the human race as an "evolved system" which arose "without intention or purpose", is very much a matter of ongoing debate.
 
 As for the global heat distribution system, that's straightforward thermodynamics. No 'thermostats' needed.
 
 

 And even the physical thermostat we are discussion does not act from teleology - its purely mechanical and made of bits of stuff.

 It's incredibly dumb stuff like this that makes me wonder why I don't simply relegate you to trhe ranks of the numbskulls I seldom take notice of!
 
 

 And note well its adaptive without any inputs from a human.

 A man-made artefact with no "inputs from a human". Do you never listen to what comes out of your own mouth?
 
 

 If it gets colder out it will burn more fuel to compensate. However this is not a heritable trait.

 Well, here you got one thing right, even if it is an observation from right out of left field. You do amaze me with your ability to find something utterly irrelevent and impertinent to add to a conversation.
